Fig. 1 (a) CO, (b) HC and (c) NO conversion on fresh catalysts (OD-f and IM-f) and aged catalysts (OD-a and IM-a). Fig 1 Fig. 2 Arrhenius plots of the turnover frequency (TOF) for (a) CO and (b) C3H6 oxidation on fresh catalysts (OD-f and IM-f) and aged catalysts (OD-a and IM-a). Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) XRD patterns and (b) histogram about the related diffraction intensity of Pt (111) of fresh and aged catalysts; CO-DRIFTS spectra of (c) fresh catalysts and (d) aged catalysts after the reduction pretreatment collected at room temperature under 2 vol.% CO/N2 flow. Fig 3 Fig. 4 TEM images and particle size distribution (inset) of fresh and aged catalysts: (a) OD-f, 50 nm; (b) IM-f, 50 nm; (d) OD-a, 50 nm; (e) IM-a, 50 nm; HR-TEM images as well as the amplified image about normalized image intensities in different directions from the 2D particle: (c) OD-f, 2 nm (f) IM-f, 2 nm. Fig 7 Fig. 8 In situ DRIFT spectra of fresh and aged catalysts in 1000 ppm NO + 5 vol.% O2/N2 flow at a function temperature from 50 to 350 °C: (a) OD-f; (b) IM-f; (c) OD-a; (d) IM-a. Sintering resistance of Pt-based oxidation catalyst via constructing Pt/MnOx interface Yanli Liang Conceptualization Data curation Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Jianli Wang Funding acquisition Supervision b ⁎ Ming Zhao Funding acquisition Supervision b Yaoqiang Chen Supervision b a School of Chemistry Engineering, Sichuan University of Science and Engineering, Zigong, 643000, PR China School of Chemistry Engineering Sichuan University of Science and Engineering Zigong 643000 PR China aSchool of Chemistry Engineering, Sichuan University of Science and Engineering, Zigong, 643000, PR China b Sichuan Provincial Environmental Protection Environmental Catalytic Materials, Engineering Technology Center, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, PR China Sichuan Provincial Environmental Protection Environmental Catalytic Materials Engineering Technology Center College of Chemistry Sichuan University Chengdu Sichuan 610064 PR China bSichuan Provincial Environmental Protection Environmental Catalytic Materials, Engineering Technology Center, College of Chemistry, Sichuan University, Chengdu, Sichuan 610064, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. It is a challenge to improve the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of platinum-based catalyst in concurrently oxidizing CO/C3H6/NO. The construction of Pt/MnOx interface over Pt-based diesel oxidation catalyst via overlayer deposition to form partial-embedded structure, inhibiting the aggregation of platinum nanoparticles in Ostwald Ripening process. Even after hydrothermal aging, the average platinum particle size is equal to that of the fresh catalyst via traditional impregnation method. The electronic-transferring from platinum to manganese results in a weaker CO adsorption ability on Pt species and an improved oxygen activation ability with the help of the redox cycle of Pt and MnOx, as well as the formation of more active nitrate species via in situ DRIFTs. Measurement on the activity shows the lower apparent activation energy, so that the light-off temperature of CO/C3H6/NO on the partial-embedded catalyst via overlayer deposition method decreases by around 20 °C and 40% NO maximum conversion still keeps after severely aging comparing with the traditional catalyst. The work enlightens us the importance of interface sites in stabilizing platinum atoms and creating oxidize active sites. Graphical abstract In comparing to impregnation method (IM), overlayer deposition method (OD) creates more Pt/MnOx interface, arresting the aggregation of platinum nanoparticles and enhancing the oxidation catalytic performance. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Interface structure Overlayer deposition Platinum Stability Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. Introduction Diesel oxidation catalysts (DOCs) is critical component in diesel aftertreatment system combined with diesel particulate filter (DPF), selective catalytic reduction (SCR) and ammonia slip catalyst (ASC) [1]. To meet the increasingly stringent emission limits, DOCs are required to address the key challenge of improved low-temperature performance for a high efficiency on SCR [2]. Beside, the stability of DOC is also considered when DOC is exposed at the temperature higher than 600 °C for the active regeneration of adjacent DPF [3]. These two questions propel that a novel DOC would be designed in improving the low temperature and stability. Pt-based diesel oxidation catalysts are most common in commercial application for its high efficiency [4,5]. While, the easily aggregation of platinum could degrade the catalytic oxidation performance, which is the main disadvantage of Pt-based catalysts in the diesel oxidation. Generally, the enhancement of Pt stability mainly focuses on the research about metal-support interfaces [6,7] Li group [8] reported an active and stable catalyst for the active Pt1(II)-Ox- species specifically stabilized by Ba-Ox- species. After 650 °C hydrothermal aging, the atomically dispersed Pt retains the original full dispersion and similar CO TOF. Peden group [9] developed a well-defined cub octahedral MgAl2O4 spinel that could stabilize Pt particles in 1–3 nm after aging at 800 °C in air for 1 week. Previous works have found that the interface of Pt and CeO2 or MnOx is beneficial to improve the hydrothermal stability of catalysts [10,11]. Beside, metal/oxide interface creates the electronic effect and this region is chemically active, affecting the activation of reaction molecule and its subsequent transformation [12,13]. In simulated diesel emission exhaust gases, there exists a competitive oxidation of CO, hydrocarbon and NO in lean burn on DOC, in which CO is more preferentially adsorbed on active sites than C3H6, resulting in that the CO oxidation is prior to the C3H6 oxidation [14–17]. For CO oxidation, it is activity-structure correlations, especially on atomically dispersed metals [18,19]. Here, attention should be paid to weaken the CO adsorption via the promotion strategies. Recently, Guo et al. [20] reported the Pt-based catalyst modified by transition metal oxides for CO oxidation at ambient temperature, based on the strong interaction between Pt and promoters, which inhibits the CO adsorption. The similar idea has been adopted by BASF Company, [21] manganese oxides were introduced to improve the HC conversion and NO oxidation to NO2 in New European Driving Cycle (NEDC) testing. Thus, the addition of cheap 3d transition metal like MnOx to modify Pt-based DOC in particles size of platinum species turns to be more feasible in practical application. The interfacial formation is to tune the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) of metals with reducible supports, including thermal treatment, reducing agent, reduction-oxidation cycles, and overlayer deposition so on [22,23]. Covering with an oxide overlayer is not only the basic function of stabilizing the metal nanoparticles, but also further applied to create specific interaction sites. Duan et al. [24] prepared Pt/MnO2@Mn3O4-I via synchronous reduction of segmental MnO2 and Pt precursor. Partial MnO2 are reduced to Mn3O4 and both have the strong interaction with Pt, thus forming the unique three-phase interfacial structure of Pt and MnO2@ Mn3O4. Wu et al. [25] developed the core-shell structure Pt @transition metal oxides(TMOs) supported on 3DOM-Al2O3 via mixing the obtained Pt/3DOM-Al2O3 and TM nitrates under precipitation agent(NH3·H2O). Sakae et al. [26] covered Pt metal nanoparticles supported on graphene oxide with metal oxide(TiO2 or ZrO2) nanosheets whose thicknesses of several nanometers to preferentially form of Pt/ metal oxide interfaces. This example emphasizes the importance of thin overlayer oxide, avoiding the coverage of the metal sites. Thus, herein we synthesize the partial-embedded MnOx overlayer on Pt-based catalyst with the aid of carbon layer from polymer to form the described interface-confined effect [27]. The method could preferentially utilize the interface for catalytic performance, while the catalyst prepared with conventional impregnation method has the exposed nano-platinum surfaces and some interfaces. The impact of interface on electronic transport and structure transformation in Pt-based catalyst via transmission electron microscope (TEM) and Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform (DRIFTs) studies will be discussed, providing a potential strategy for constructing interface in the preparation of highly efficient and stable oxidation catalysts. Experimental section Catalyst preparation (1) Traditional impregnation method: The Pt(NO3)2 solution and Mn(NO3)2 solution were impregnated on SiO2-Al2O3 powder (150 m2/g, Solway), containing 1 mass% Pt and a moral ratio of Pt/Mn=1:1. Then the catalyst is obtained after dried and calcined with the total wash-coated loading amount of each sample was about 140 g/L, as the previous method [28], which is labeled as IM-f. (2) Designed overlayer deposition method: Firstly, the Pt(NO3)2 solution and small amount polyvinyl alcohol were impregnated on SiO2-Al2O3 powder (150 m2/g, Solway), and the carbonized Pt/SiO2-Al2O3 is prepared from the previous work [29]. The obtained powder was impregnated by Mn(NO3)2 solution with the equal molar ratio of Pt with the loading amount of 1 wt%. Dried at 60 °C and calcined at 800 °C for 2 h under N2, and then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h (Scheme 1 ). The powder was wash-coated onto cylindrical cordierite monoliths with loading amount of each sample was about 140 g/L. The obtained monolithic catalysts were then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h in air and labeled as OD-f. Similar method have applied to the transitional metals (Co, Fe), as shown in Supporting information. The fresh catalysts OD-f and IM-f were aged at 700 °C for 10 h under the mixed simulated diesel react gasses: 200 ppm NO, 600 ppm C3H6, 1500 ppm CO, 5% O2, 8% H2O, and 4% CO2, using N2 as balance (800 mL/min). The final aged catalysts were labeled as OD-a and IM-a, respectively. Catalytic evaluation The catalytic performance of catalysts is evaluated according to the previous work [11]. The reactant conversion was defined by the following Eqs. (1)–(3): (1) CO conversion (%) = ([CO]inlet -[CO]outlet)/[CO]inlet*100% (2) HC conversion (%) = ([HC]inlet -[HC]outlet)/[HC]inlet*100% (3) NO conversion (%) = [NO2]outlet /([NO]outlet +[NO2]outlet)*100% Where[CO]inlet, [HC]inlet, [CO]outlet, [HC]outlet, [NO2]outlet and [NO]outlet were was the volumetric concentration of the corresponding species in the inlet and outlet gas mixture respectively. Catalyst characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of powdered samples were recorded with a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). CO- diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTs) was adopted on Thermo Nicolet 6700 to obtain the spectra of CO adsorption on Pt species. High Resolution-Transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) measurement was performed by using Bruker Nano GmbH with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) data were performed with an electron spectrometer (XSAM-800, Kratos Co.) equipped with an Al Kα radiation as a primary excitation. Binding energies were calculated on the basis of C 1s at 284.6 eV.H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were used to measure the redox properties. CO-temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) experiments were adopted on the similar measurement to TPR. In situ DRIFTs spectra were obtained on the FTIR instruments (FTIR, Thermo Nicolet 6700). The detailed information is presented in Supporting information. Results and discussions Catalytic performance and heat stability Fig. 1 shows the DOC catalytic performance of fresh and aged Pt-based catalysts containing manganese prepared with different methods. The OD-f catalyst is significantly more active than the IM-f. For example, the temperature values required for 50% CO/C3H6 and 30% NO conversion are at 187 °C, 200 °C and 224 °C on OD-f, respectively, while that on IM-f are at 213 °C, 226 °C and 267 °C, respectively. And the maximum conversion (57%) of NO for OD-f is higher than that (which is about 37%) for IM-f. Fig. S1 shows the reproducibility on OD-f after three rounds of activity tests. No distinct difference could be presented on OD-f, indicating its great repeatability. After aging at 700 °C for 10 h in the mixed reaction gases including 8 vol.% H2O, the catalytic activity of both Pt-based catalysts in CO/C3H6/NO oxidation for the serious platinum aggregation in Ostwald Ripening process. Similar trends in light-off temperature and NO maximum conversion are presented on the aged catalysts OD-a and IM-a. For all conversions as shown in Fig. 1, a lower light-off temperature (around 10 °C) and higher NO maximum (around 5%) conversion on OD-a could be found when comparing on IM-f, indicating the excellent stability of the OD-a. The big difference in performance could be contributed to the preferential utilization of metal/oxide interface. In oxidation process, O2 adsorbs on the interface where the bond of O2 could be weakened, and then easily be activated to react [30]. Related apparent activation energy (Ea) is calculated from Arrhenius plots of turnover frequency (TOF) for CO and C3H6 oxidation reactions. In the case of CO oxidation reaction (Fig. 2 (a)), apparent activation energy on OD-f is about 66.1 kJ/mol, which is slightly smaller than that on IM-f (around 74.4 kJ/mol), indicating a better CO catalytic activity on OD-f. While for C3H6 oxidation reaction in Fig. 2(b), there is a remarkable difference in apparent activation energy between fresh and aged catalysts. Ea(C3H6) on OD-f and IM-f are around 193.9 kJ/mol and 207.5 kJ/mol, respectively. The results identify the better oxidation activity on OD-f. Likewise on aged catalysts, Ea(C3H6) on OD-a catalyst decreases by 115 kJ/mol than on IM-a catalyst. The kinetic behavior on all catalysts further explains the superior catalytic oxidation on OD catalysts not only on fresh one but also on aged one. Reaction condition: CO 1000 ppm, C3H6 330 ppm, NO 200 ppm, O2 10 vol.%, H2O 7 vol.%, CO2 8 vol.%, N2 balance, GHSV 60 kh−1; Aging condition: 600 ppm C3H6, 1500 ppm CO, 200 ppm NO, H2O 8 vol.%, 5 vol.% O2, 4 vol.% CO2, and N2 balance, at 700 °C for 10 h. The designed impregnation method has been extended to Fe/Co elements, and the detailed preparation process have been recorded in supporting information. Fig. S2 shows their CO/C3H6 total conversion temperature below at 200 °C and 210 °C, respectively; 30% NO conversion temperature around at 225 °C and NO maximum conversion up to around 60%. The results suggest the applicability of designed impregnation method in transitional metals (Fe/Co/Mn), thus providing the potential ability in application for eliminating emission. Structural properties X-ray diffraction patterns are presented to present the Pt crystallinity. And standard Mn2O3 and Pt cards are also presented in Fig. 3 (a). All catalysts containing fresh state and aged state have the weak Mn2O3 phase and the obvious platinum and support (γ-Al2O3) [28] phase. Paying attention to the characteristic (111) reflections of platinum at 39.8°, an obvious difference in diffraction intensity between fresh and aged catalysts is observed, as shown in Fig. 3(b). OD-f has the lowest diffraction intensity of Pt phase, indicating a higher platinum dispersion on OD-f than on IM-f. After hydrothermal aging, the degree of Pt crystallinity on both catalysts has a serve increase, reflecting a degraded Pt dispersion on aged catalysts. In Fig. 3(b), the diffraction intensity of Pt (111) on OD-a is about three times of that on OD-f, being equivalent to that on IM-f. The interesting results clearly reveal the higher catalytic oxidation performance on OD-f and OD-a than on IM-f, which are mainly contributed to the lower platinum crystallinity. To further investigate the exposed platinum sites, the probe molecule (CO) was introduced on the reduced catalysts at room temperature. In Fig. 3(c), there appears the vibration of gas CO (2100–2200 cm−1) and CO linear adsorption on Pt0 (2000–2100 cm−1). It is generally thought that higher CO adsorption intensity indicate the more exposed platinum sites. A strange result is observed that OD-f with a smaller aggregated degree has a weaker CO adsorption intensity than IM-f. Meanwhile, an intensive CO adsorption on Pt0 at 2072 cm−1 appears on IM-f with a shoulder peak at 2086 cm−1, while the peak of CO-Pt0 shifts to a higher wavenumber (2080 cm−1) on OD-f. Bonding occurs on the metal surface should obey the matches of energy level and the orbital direction from Blyholder model [31]. The 5σ orbital of CO and the unoccupied d-orbital of Pt atom could occur hybridization, forming platinum-carbon-oxygen bond. A large formal negative charge is given to Pt atoms, resulting in the back-donation from Pt d-orbital to 2π* orbital of CO in order to remove excess negative charge and make the bond stable. Thus, if the reduction of platinum atom in d electrons could weaken the bond of Pt-CO. In the interfacial region of oxides with high electron affinity and metals with low work function via deposition could induce the reduction of the oxide by direct electron transfer, leading to electron rich of oxide surface [32]. The blue shift on OD-f is contributed to the electron transfer from Pt to Mn, which is greatly speculated as the original reasons for its weaker CO-Pt0 peak. The weaker back-donation from d orbital (Pt) to π* orbital (adsorbed CO) could decrease the CO adsorbed intensity on OD-f. The phenomenon is similar as the report from a patent [21]. The less impact of CO poisoning on Pt is thereby beneficial to CO oxidation reaction especially at low temperature. Meanwhile for the aged catalysts, severe aggregation of platinum particles would greatly decrease in the exposed platinum species. According to our previous work [33], the particle size not valence state of platinum on the aged catalysts is crucial in improving catalytic performance. Here, the interaction of nano-MnOx and nano-Pt could inhibit the sintering in the Ostwald ripening, resulting in its relatively more platinum species exposed on OD-a compared to IM-a catalyst. As shown in Fig. 3(d), OD-a shows a stronger adsorption intensity of Pt0-CO than IM-a, verifying that the OD-a has more active platinum sites and great stability. In Fig. 4 , the distribution and growth of Pt after annealing on support is confirmed by the TEM and HRTEM images where Pt active phases are clearly resolved. In the fresh state (Fig. 4(a, b)), black Pt particles of OD-f catalyst become smaller and more homogeneously dispersed than that of IM-f. During hydrothermal aging, Pt nanoparticles on both catalysts grow up, as shown in Fig. 4(d, e). The initially large average platinum particles on IM-f grow even larger on IM-a, while a minor aggregation is displayed in OD-a compared with IM-a. Associating with the distribution of platinum inserted in Fig. 4(d-e), the frequency of small particles (d<4 nm) on OD-a is around 10%, yet less than 5% on IM-a, indicating the less aggregation appearing on OD-a. Further to the lattice fringe of Pt nanoparticles, Fig. 4(c) and (f) show the interplanar distances of 0.23 nm, corresponding to the (111) plane of platinum phases on both fresh catalysts. In particular, partial region with the lattice fringe of 0.27 nm is detected for OD-f on the surface of platinum particle, assigning to the Mn2O3 (222) phase. While no Mn2O3 is detected in the vicinity of nano-Pt on IM-f, indicating the weak interaction between platinum and manganese via traditional impregnation in the situation. The partial-embedded Mn2O3 on Pt nanoparticle verifies that Mn2O3 overlayers deposition on the surface of Pt-based catalyst. The formed interface region on OD-f exists the strong interaction of Pt with manganese and inhibits the aggregation of platinum nanoparticles. After statistical calculation from TEM results in Table 1 , the average platinum particle size of OD-f is 3.9 nm, which is the smallest measurement obtained, and its Pt dispersion is 30.2%. While in the case of the IM-f catalyst, the average Pt particle size is around twice than of OD-f. This trend is accordance to the XRD results. After hydrothermal aging, Pt particle agglomeration resulted in a sharply decrease of Pt dispersion on OD-a (14.1%) and IM-a (10.3%). The obvious inhibit effect of dispersion on aged catalyst might be contributed to the formation of partial-embedded structure on OD-f, which greatly promotes the anti-sintering of platinum. The lattice fringe in HR-TEM patterns could verify the construction of partial-embedded structure on OD-f, creating the interface-confined effect which inhibits the aggregation of platinum nanoparticles in Ostwald Ripening. The improved Pt dispersion on OD-f is beneficial to its better catalytic performance, comparing to IM-f. Beside, the formation of interface could affect the electronic state of platinum. Platinum chemical state Fig. 5 shows the Pt 4f (Al 2p) curves of surface platinum (Al) element on the fresh catalysts. The Pt 4f7/2 peak and the 4f5/2 peak from spin-orbit splitting are divided in assigning Pt0 (70.6 eV [36] and 74.0 eV), PtO (73.4 and 76.8 eV) and PtO2 (74.8 and 78.2 eV). By calculating the proportion of Pt0, OD-f and IM-f have the ratio of Pt0/Ptn+(n = 2, 4) as 28.5% and 32.3%, respectively, indicating that a slightly more oxidation state of platinum exists in surficial layer. Due to the overlapped Pt 4f with Al 2p, the difference in element portion is not obvious. To further investigate the variation in chemical state of platinum, the redox properties of catalysts were also investigated by the H2-TPR experiment. In Fig. 6 (a), the reduction temperature of platinum oxides on both catalysts is similar at around 94 °C. Total H2 consumption area on OD-f is a slightly higher of 22.9% than that on IM-f, which is line with the blue shift on CO-Pt0 in Section 3.2. Previous studies about the chemical state of platinum have been investigated on the aged catalysts, and it is found that the particle size of platinum is mainly important for catalytic oxidation performance [33]. After reduction treatment of CO, partial reduced platinum species adsorb CO at room temperature and then desorb at elevated temperature, as shown in Fig. 6(b). After reduction, the formation of semi-embed structure on OD-f could induce the oxygen from MnOx transformation to oxidize the reduced Pt species. According to the action mode of CO adsorption on Pt, the more formation of PtOx would be more easily to desorb CO, so that OD-f has a higher CO desorption amount of 10.4% than IM-f. The construction of interface on OD-f would promote the formation of platinum oxides for the electron transfer from Mn to Pt. The decreased electronic density of Pt could weaken CO adsorption ability appearing on OD-f. According to the characteristic sequence of oxidation reaction (CO, C3H6 and NO), the better CO catalytic performance could promote the following NO oxidation reaction. NOx adsorption and desorption behavior by in situ DRIFTs Detecting the reaction process is beneficial to investigate the original discrepancy of catalysts. Before reaction, the initial adsorption behaviors of reaction molecules are crucial for the following temperature rising. Fig. 7 presents the co-adsorption curves of NO and O2 at 50 °C as a function of time using in situ DRIFTs [37]. At 1 min, the band at 1630 cm−1 firstly appears on the surface of OD-f, assigning to the bridged nitrates. With the increased time to 5 min, bridged nitrates become saturated adsorption. At 10 min, a new band assigned to the chelating nitrates at 1601 cm−1 appears. Further to 20 min, ionic nitrates (1370 and 1396 cm−1) gradually form. Increasing with the adsorption time to 40 min, all nitrates present an increased adsorption intensity in Fig. 7(a), and the intensity of bridged/chelating nitrates is stronger than that of ionic nitrates. Similar adsorption experiments were adopted on IM-f in Fig. 7(b). However, there has a big difference in surficial adsorption species, compared to Fig. 7(a). Expect for the bridged nitrates, ionic nitrates with same intensity have also appeared at 1 min. Along with the appearance of chelating nitrates at 10 min, the intensity of ionic nitrates is stronger. The rising tendency continue to the adsorption saturation at 40 min, resulting in the more formation of ionic nitrates than chelating/bridged nitrates. Stable ionic nitrates are uneasy to decompose, which might affect the form rate of final product. Fig. 7(c) and (d) show the co-adsorption spectra of NO and O2 on the aged catalysts as the parallel comparison. Obviously, more ionic nitrates and less bridged nitrates form on the aged catalysts, comparing to the adsorption species on fresh catalysts. In detail, ionic nitrates quickly form on OD-a at 1 min and continually increases up to 30 min, along with the relatively weaker bridged nitrates appearing from 1 min to 30 min and chelating nitrates appearing from 15 min to 30 min. Meanwhile for IM-a, the similar weak intensity of ionic nitrates and bridged nitrates emerge at 1 min. With an accelerating time, then intensity of ionic nitrates gradually increases, yet no variation in bridged nitrates. Finally, OD-a has a lower intensity of ionic nitrates than IM-a. After the saturated adsorption at 50 °C, then the spectra were recorded as a function of temperature up to 350 °C as an interval of 100 °C. In Fig. 8 (a), a portion of bridged nitrites appearing at around 1326 cm−1 forms on OD-f catalyst at 150 °C and then decreases at 350 °C. Similar variation in the formation and reduction of nitrites occurs on the IM-f catalyst (Fig. 8(b)). And ionic/bridged/ chelating nitrates present the decreased trend with an elevated temperature. Especially at 350 °C, most of ionic nitrates have decomposed to form the micro molecule, resulting in a sharply decreases. For the aged catalysts, monodentate nitrates (1553 cm−1, 1534 cm−1) forms at 150 °C and gradually decreases to 350 °C. It could be found that the ionic nitrates have an obvious decreased tendency on OD-a from 150 to 350 °C, yet no change appears on IM-a indicating its more difficult decomposition and less NO2 formation. Based on the above-mentioned experimental results, advanced Pt-based diesel oxidation catalyst via deposition method reveal the great catalytic performance and stability, where are some following reasons: (i) the higher dispersion of Pt before and after aging exist on OD, which could maintain the more exposed platinum sites for oxidizing process; (ii) the strong electronic transferring from manganese to platinum induce the positive electron on platinum atoms, weakening the CO strong-adsorption ability and facilitating the first-step CO oxidation process; (iii) In addition, the detected partial-embedded MnOx on platinum particle contribute to the first two, which promote the formation of nitrates in NO oxidation process and finally contribute to the superior catalytic activity and stability. Conclusions A designed overlayer deposition method was adopted to prepare the Pt/oxide interface via the formation of partial-embed structure over Pt-based catalysts, which greatly improved the catalytic performance and hydrothermal stability on CO/C3H6/NO oxidation. Their light-off temperature decreased by around 20 °C and 40% NO maximum conversion is still kept after severely aging, comparing to the catalyst prepared by traditional impregnation method. The formation of interface between Pt and MnOx results in a decrease in the apparent activity energy of CO/C3H6 and then a weaken in CO adsorption on platinum due to the electron transferring from Pt to manganese. The electron transferring from Pt to manganese further promotes the redox property, enhancing the oxygen activation ability. The partial-embed structure causing the interface-confinement could arrest the aggregation of platinum nanoparticles, improving the platinum dispersion before and after aging. And it results in the more active surficial nitrate species. Comparing with the patent [38] that CO T50 of only-Pt catalyst (1 mass% Pt) via colloidal method was 208 °C, our reported catalyst has a better low-temperature activity under a higher GHSV. In summary, the construction of interface-confinement is available for enhancing the platinum dispersion and oxygen activation, extending noble-metal oxidation catalysis to the realm of industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: It is a challenge to improve the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of platinum-based catalyst in concurrently oxidizing CO/C3H6/NO. The construction of Pt/MnOx interface over Pt-based diesel oxidation catalyst via overlayer deposition to form partial-embedded structure, inhibiting the aggregation of platinum nanoparticles in Ostwald Ripening process. Even after hydrothermal aging, the average platinum particle size is equal to that of the fresh catalyst via traditional impregnation method. The electronic-transferring from platinum to manganese results in a weaker CO adsorption ability on Pt species and an improved oxygen activation ability with the help of the redox cycle of Pt and MnOx, as well as the formation of more active nitrate species via in situ DRIFTs. Measurement on the activity shows the lower apparent activation energy, so that the light-off temperature of CO/C3H6/NO on the partial-embedded catalyst via overlayer deposition method decreases by around 20 °C and 40% NO maximum conversion still keeps after severely aging comparing with the traditional catalyst. The work enlightens us the importance of interface sites in stabilizing platinum atoms and creating oxidize active sites.
coredata.dc:title: Sintering resistance of Pt-based oxidation catalyst via constructing Pt/MnOx interface
